title: Death Toll Rises to Seven in Texas Rampage
text:
The death toll from a shooting rampage in West Texas rose to seven on Sunday as officials identified the gunman, but remained unsure about his motive.

The gunman, identified by law-enforcement officials as 36-year-old Seth Ator, shot at least 21 people as he drove between Odessa and nearby Midland Saturday afternoon, firing at random and hijacking a U.S. Postal Service van, authorities said. Ator died when officers intercepted him outside a movie theater.

Two victims died overnight Saturday, officials confirmed, raising the death toll to seven. Twenty-two others were injured, according to law enforcement. Those killed ranged in age from 15 to 57.

A local student was killed in the attacks, the Ector County school district wrote on Facebook . A 17-month-old girl was among the wounded. Three law-enforcement officers were shot: a Texas Department of Public Safety trooper, an Odessa police officer and a Midland police officer, officials said.

In a news conference Sunday, officials praised local law enforcement for stopping the shooter, speculating that he may have been heading into the Cinergy movie theater when he was killed.

“Why would you go to a theater if you’re not planning on going into the theater?” Police Chief Michael Gerke said, adding that the movie theater is one of the most crowded places in Odessa on a Saturday.

FBI Special Agent Christopher Combs said hundreds of federal personnel are on the ground, from the FBI and other agencies. He confirmed federal authorities were executing a search warrant on a home on the western side of the city and said, with over 15 crime scenes, locals should expect to see FBI activity.

Mr. Turner said there is no indication that the shooter had any particular ideology. “I think it’s just someone with some problems,” he said. Law-enforcement officials Sunday said they didn’t suspect that Ator had ties to domestic or international terror groups.

Mr. Turner added that the rampage hit the city hard.

The shooter was killed by the police after opening fire in Midland and Odessa PHOTO: MARK ROGERS/ASSOCIATED PRESS

“The city is hurting,” he said. “We’re already starting to see the politicization of what happened, but right now, we’re coming together as a city. The outpouring of prayer and support has been amazing, from blood, to food, to water, to taking care of our first responders. Today begins the healing process.”

The shooting began at around 3:15 p.m. local time Saturday when the DPS trooper attempted to stop a gold sedan for failing to signal.

Before the vehicle came to a stop, the suspect pointed a rifle toward the rear window of his car and fired several shots toward the DPS patrol unit, hitting a trooper, according to a statement from the DPS.

The suspect then drove into Odessa, where he began targeting people at random. At some point, the suspect ditched his car, stole a U.S. mail truck and continued shooting people. Officers ultimately shot the suspect, Chief Gerke said. He was killed at the Cinergy movie theater in Odessa.

The trooper is in serious but stable condition, and the two other officers are in stable condition at a local hospital, according to the DPS statement.

The 17-month-old girl was sent to University Medical Center in Lubbock, where she was in satisfactory condition Saturday night, said Eric Finley, marketing director at UMC Health System. Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said Sunday that the girl was slated to have surgery Monday.

The shooting comes less than a month after mass shootings in Texas and Ohio left at least 31 dead and about 50 injured in the space of 24 hours. Twenty-two of the dead were killed by a gunman in an El Paso Walmart .

On Sunday, Gov. Abbott recounted the string of mass shootings he has seen during his tenure in Texas, saying “the status quo in the state of Texas is not acceptable.”

“I have been to too many of these events as governor,” he said. “I am heartbroken by the crying of the people of the state of Texas. I’m tired of the dying of the people of the state of Texas.”

Gov. Abbott said he and other lawmakers are meeting daily to discuss possible solutions to such shootings. He said this most recent rampage “absolutely” gives greater urgency to that effort.

Still, he defended 15 new laws that went into effect Sunday, largely loosening restrictions on guns. He said some of them, including a provision making it easier to arm officers at schools, aim to make communities safer.

Friends of Leila Hernandez, one of the victims of the Saturday shooting in Odessa, gather at a memorial service on Sunday. Photo: Sue Ogrocki/Associated Press

President Trump said he was briefed about Saturday’s shooting by Attorney General William Barr.

Mr. Trump told reporters Sunday at the White House that the shooter was a “very sick person.” He said his administration is still weighing a policy response to mass shootings and continues to talk to lawmakers. Mr. Trump said better background checks “would not have stopped” many recent mass shootings.

The shootings in Texas “really hasn’t changed anything” in terms of the policy options being considered, he said.

During a briefing on Hurricane Dorian Sunday afternoon, Mr. Trump called for “strong measures to keep weapons out of the hands of dangerous and deranged individuals and substantial reforms to the nation’s broken mental health system.” He also said it is his goal to identify “severely disturbed individuals” and stop them before they can harm the public.

Trump administration officials have been meeting with lawmakers and congressional staffers since mass shootings in Ohio and Texas last month left 31 dead. But it remains unclear whether there is enough political will in Congress to move gun control legislation.

Acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan said Sunday the shootings across the nation are “absolutely a homeland security threat” and that what he called domestic terrorism has taken a “frontline focus” within the department’s counterterrorism strategy and approach.

Sen. Rick Scott (R., Fla.), speaking on “NBC’s Meet the Press,” said Sunday Congress should focus on the kind of legislation Florida passed after the Parkland, Fla., shooting more than a year ago, which he supported, that helped to identify individuals who exhibit troubling behavior.

A “red-flag law” gives law enforcement and courts the authority to potentially seize all weapons from anyone who has threatened to harm themselves or someone else, he said. Florida legislators also added a provision that will provide law-enforcement officers to each school and more mental-health counselors to help identify problems before they happen, he said.

Mr. Scott stopped short of saying he would support an assault-weapons ban or other measures that would remove weapons from the streets.

Meanwhile, Democratic presidential candidates pressed for tighter gun laws. Former Housing Secretary Julián Castro, a Texan, told MSNBC that stricter gun controls should be in place, as well as higher taxes on firearms and ammunition.

“This, just three weeks after what we saw in El Paso, is tremendously heartbreaking for the entire nation but, of course, especially for those of us in Texas,” he said. “How many of these incidents do we have to see before we understand that we have to take action?”

The League of United Latin American Citizens asked the governor Saturday to call a special legislative session on guns. The Texas legislature meets every other year for five months, and isn’t set to convene until 2021.

—Ken Thomas, Andrew Restuccia, Sadie Gurman and Dan Frosch contributed to this article.
description: The death toll from a shooting rampage in West Texas rose to seven as officials identified the gunman, but remained unsure about his motive.
